00.orig_text: Apple executive leaves company after iPhone 4 antenna issues
00.text: Apple executive leaves company after iPhone 4 antenna issues

02.orig_text: Mark Papermaster, formerly an Apple Inc. executive overseeing hardware engineering for the company's iPhone, is stepping down from his post.
02.text: Mark Papermaster, formerly an Apple Inc. executive overseeing hardware engineering for the company's iPhone, is stepping down from his post.

03.orig_text: The move came after Apple received criticism last month for the placement of the antenna on their most recent iPhone model, iPhone 4.
03.text: The move came after Apple received criticism last month for the placement of the antenna on their most recent iPhone model, iPhone 4.

04.orig_text: Apple confirmed that Papermaster, 49, had left the company, but did not say whether he decided to leave or was forced out.
04.text: Apple confirmed that Papermaster, 49, had left the company, but did not say whether he decided to leave or was forced out.

05.orig_text: Papermaster did not comment on the situation.
05.text: Papermaster did not comment on the situation.

06.orig_text: According to The New York Times, who first broke the news about Papermaster's departure, an anonymous individual ``with direct knowledge of the situation`` claimed that the former executive had been ousted over various hardware issues, some related to the iPod Touch.
06.text: According to The New York Times, who first broke the news about Papermaster's departure, an anonymous individual ``with direct knowledge of the situation`` claimed that the former executive had been ousted over various hardware issues, some related to the iPod Touch.

07.orig_text: When Apple CEO Steve Jobs first introduced iPhone 4, he praised the device's antenna design.
07.text: When Apple CEO Steve Jobs first introduced iPhone 4, he praised the device's antenna design.

08.orig_text: However, many consumers reported that, when holding the phone in a certain location, reception would decrease and sometimes lead to dropped calls.
08.text: However, many consumers reported that, when holding the phone in a certain location, reception would decrease and sometimes lead to dropped calls.

09.orig_text: Apple's response to the issue, dubbed ``Antennagate`` by the media, was first to recommend holding the phone in a different location.
09.text: Apple's response to the issue, dubbed ``Antennagate`` by the media, was first to recommend holding the phone in a different location.

10.orig_text: They later found a related software glitch that caused the signal strength to be misreported on the device.
10.text: They later found a related software glitch that caused the signal strength to be misreported on the device.

11.orig_text: In a July 16 press conference, Jobs said that all iPhone 4 buyers would be eligible to receive a free case, or ``bumper,`` which alleviates the signal problem.
11.text: In a July 16 press conference, Jobs said that all iPhone 4 buyers would be eligible to receive a free case, or ``bumper,`` which alleviates the signal problem.

12.orig_text: Citing people familiar with the situation, The Wall Street Journal reported that Papermaster had been pushed out due to an incompatibility with Apple's corporate culture.
12.text: Citing people familiar with the situation, The Wall Street Journal reported that Papermaster had been pushed out due to an incompatibility with Apple's corporate culture.

13.orig_text: The sources claimed that Papermaster was not used to the environment or corporate politics and did not possess the creativity the company wanted to see.
13.text: The sources claimed that Papermaster was not used to the environment or corporate politics and did not possess the creativity the company wanted to see.

14.orig_text: They also said that it was Jobs, not Papermaster, who made the decision to proceed with iPhone 4 development even though the company had been aware of potential signal problems resulting from the antenna placement as early as a year ago.
14.text: They also said that it was Jobs, not Papermaster, who made the decision to proceed with iPhone 4 development even though the company had been aware of potential signal problems resulting from the antenna placement as early as a year ago.

15.orig_text: Papermaster's post will be filled by Bob Mansfield, Apple's senior vice president for Macintosh engineering.
15.text: Papermaster's post will be filled by Bob Mansfield, Apple's senior vice president for Macintosh engineering.

16.orig_text: Mansfield was already involved in iPhone development, overseeing processor and display engineering.
16.text: Mansfield was already involved in iPhone development, overseeing processor and display engineering.

17.orig_text: Papermaster had been with Apple since November 2008, but a United States federal judge barred him from working until April 2009.
17.text: Papermaster had been with Apple since November 2008, but a United States federal judge barred him from working until April 2009.

18.orig_text: He had previously held a senior position with IBM, where he had worked for 25 years.
18.text: He had previously held a senior position with IBM, where he had worked for 25 years.

19.orig_text: IBM sued Papermaster in an attempt to block him from joining Apple, but a settlement was reached after he testified that no IBM corporate secrets had been disclosed to Apple.
19.text: IBM sued Papermaster in an attempt to block him from joining Apple, but a settlement was reached after he testified that no IBM corporate secrets had been disclosed to Apple.
